title: Developmental programming modulates olfactory behavior in <italic>C. elegans</italic> via endogenous RNAi pathways
abstract: Environmental stress during early development can impact adult phenotypes via programmed changes in gene expression. <italic>C. elegans</italic> larvae respond to environmental stress by entering the stress-resistant dauer diapause pathway and resume development once conditions improve (postdauers). Here we show that the <italic>osm-9</italic> TRPV channel gene is a target of developmental programming and is down-regulated specifically in the ADL chemosensory neurons of postdauer adults, resulting in a corresponding altered olfactory behavior that is mediated by ADL in an OSM-9-dependent manner. We identify a <italic>cis</italic>-acting motif bound by the DAF-3 SMAD and ZFP-1 (AF10) proteins that is necessary for the differential regulation of <italic>osm-9,</italic> and demonstrate that both chromatin remodeling and endo-siRNA pathways are major contributors to the transcriptional silencing of the <italic>osm-9</italic> locus. This work describes an elegant mechanism by which developmental experience influences adult phenotypes by establishing and maintaining transcriptional changes via RNAi and chromatin remodeling pathways.
